title: Curriculum Development and Assessment in Early Childhood Education
requirements: For students in MA Early Childhood Education
description: This course focuses on current issues in curriculum development and assessment in early childhood education (ECE). Technical, deliberative/ practical and critical approaches to curriculum development in ECE will be explored. Participants will be encouraged to reflect on their own practices and examine issues which are likely to be covered: curriculum continuity between kindergarten and primary school; values education in the early childhood curriculum; multiple intelligences and their application in curriculum development and assessment; whole language approach; information technology in education; portfolio assessment; and sociocultural theories for early childhood curriculum.
outcome: At the end of this course, students are expected to:  1. Grasp the distinctive features of different curriculum development models; 2. Understand the principles that underpin the ECE curriculum and assessment designs; 3. Offer analysis and personal opinions on selected curriculum issues in ECE; and 4. Reflect on their own practices related to curriculum development in ECE.  (Individual course teachers may update the learning outcome as and whenever necessary.)
syllabus: 1. Trends and issues in of ECE curriculum development and assessment 2. Approaches to curriculum development and assessment 3. Developmentally appropriate practice and authentic assessment 4. Project approach and portfolio assessment 5. Play and early childhood education curriculum 6. Inclusive education in kindergartens 7. Catering learner diversities 8. Whole language approach and assessment 9. Integrated curriculum and assessment 10. Pedagogical decision making and constructivist instruction in ECE 11. Sociocultural theories and hidden curriculum in ECE  (For reference only, please refer to the course outline of respective teacher for details.)

title: Educational Leadership and Management in Early Childhood Education
requirements: For students in MA Early Childhood Education
description: This course focuses on two important aspects in early childhood education: educational leadership and management. It is to emphasize that leadership and management are of paramount importance to the success of any organization, including ECE institutions. It is leadership and management that make organizations efficient and effective. This course blends the theoretical concepts of leadership and management with practice, enabling the participants to refine and improve their practice. By the end of the course, students will be familiar with a number of theories and perspectives of leadership and management; be able to critically analyze different perspectives and theories; have developed a position on what they believe ‘good’ leadership and management entailed in Hong Kong schools in general, and more specifically within their workplace context; and be able to discuss the various educational leadership and management issues in Hong Kong schools and their relationship with educational reform.
outcome: • Appreciate the complexity of real life in school; • Develop an integrative perspective about organizational life in school; • Become an independent and critical thinker; • Employ organizational theory as a lens to interpret everyday organizational life; • Apply theories to improve organizational practice; • Explore management practices across cultural boundaries; • Understand the new roles emerging in organizations as a result of innovations in technology.  (Individual course teachers may update the learning outcome as and whenever necessary.)
syllabus: 1. Foundations of management and leadership theories 2. Structural perspective 3. Political perspective 4. Human resource perspective 5. Cultural perspective 6. Integration  (For reference only, please refer to the course outline of respective teacher for details.)

title: Comparative Education and Current Issues in Early Childhood Education
requirements: For students in MA Early Childhood Education
description: This course focuses on the current issues from a comparative perspective. It aims to expound the divergent and convergent trends among educational policies, educational practices and issues related to early childhood education. The following issues are likely to be examined: educational governance and finance; home-preschool collaboration; early childhood education and care policy; early childhood school-based curriculum reform; preschool special education, preschool improvement and new trends in early childhood educational research. Through a comparison of the rationales, initiatives in early childhood education in different societies, participants will be able to examine the local development of early childhood education in a wider context.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students are expected: 1. to have a basic understanding of general perspectives on education; 2. to be able to reflect on the meaning and significance of the key issues in early childhood education; 3. to relate their own experience to the concepts and theories learnt in the course.  (Individual course teachers may update the learning outcome as and whenever necessary.)

title: Early Childhood Development from Birth to Eight Years of Age
requirements: For students in MA Early Childhood Education
description: Studies of early childhood from birth to eighth year of age will be introduced in this course which includes the characteristic periods of infants, toddlers, preschool and kindergarten kids, and children of early primary grades. The course is to develop students’ insights into early childhood’s physical, motor, intellectual, emotional, social, and aesthetic growth. Major developmental theories/perspectives will be discussed, analyzed, and compared. The key issues that will be highlighted are concerned with developmental and learning mechanisms, domain-general and domain-specific development, and nature-nurture relationship. Reflecting upon relevant social policy and educational initiatives. The challenges will be analyzed of translating observations and theories of child development into child care and education practices at home and at school.
outcome: A. Compare and contrast the perspectives of major developmental theories which influence early childhood education. B. Demonstrate knowledge of developmental capabilities and tasks at each stage of early childhood development. C. Practice methodological approaches including observations, interviews, and developmental assessments to understand children’s behaviors. D. Demonstrate the ability to summarize and to analyze collected information on young children’s development in theoretical contexts. E. Apply developmental theories and research results in practical situations when planning for instruction, or developing facilitative interactions with children. F. Appreciate developmental differences in individual children and understand how they influence classroom practice.  (Individual course teachers may update the learning outcome as and whenever necessary.)
syllabus: The introduction of what, why, and how of the study of early childhood development Physical growth and brain development Cognitive development Social and emotional development  (For reference only, please refer to the course outline of respective teacher for details.)

title: Signs, Activities and the Development of Mind in Early Childhood
requirements: For students in MA Early Childhood Education
description: The role of sign mediation is regarded as essential in the development of higher psychological processes. In this course, you are invited to explore the rich varieties of signs and their role in the development of mind in early childhood. There are two key concerns in the course: (1) In what ways are meaning making and the development of mind related to children's experience with signs such as languages, mathematics, and visual and expressive arts? (2) How could learning activities be designed to facilitate the understanding, appropriation, and creation of signs? To deepen our understanding of the complexity involved, perspectives from semiotics and the cultural-historical activity theory would be introduced. Insights from research works on the relation between signs and thought, as well as the interaction between sign mediation and human mediation, the creation of the zone of proximal development, and the integration of signs in children's activities, would be drawn to inform the educational practice and the actual design of learning activities. Drawing from different sources of stimulations, we aim to arrive at rich possibilities of designing meaningful activities for facilitating the early development of human mind.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students are expected to be able to: 1) identify different forms of signs and their richness; 2) recognize multi-modal meaning making in children's experience with signs and the role of the signs mediation in the development of children's higher psychological processes; 3) design and/or evaluate the effectiveness of early childhood educational activities applying the rationales behind the perspectives of semiotics and cognitive theories.  (Individual course teachers may update the learning outcome as and whenever necessary.)

title: Guided Project
requirements: For students in MA Early Childhood Education
description: Participants will participate in a small project under the guidance and support of practicum supervisors. They may either undertake the project individually or in pairs if the topic and context allows. The focus of study may be related to organizational, curriculum, teaching and learning aspects in pre-schools or other early childhood educational organizations or other themes with permission of supervisor. Participants will be placed in small support groups who are expected to share experiences and exchange ideas gained from the project.
outcome: After taking this course, students will be able to: 1. Demonstrate the application of knowledge and method to the investigation of a specific area within the field of Early Childhood Education. 2. Identify an issue to which solutions and/ or recommendations can be addressed; and produce a written report which sets out clearly the aims, context, content and outcome. 3. Integrate the skills and knowledge which have been taught in the degree programme with specific application to a topic to produce a well-argued report.  (Individual course teachers may update the learning outcome as and whenever necessary.)

title: Study Tour and Report
requirements: For students in MA Early Childhood Education
description: This course aims to provide opportunity for participants to gain actual experience of early childhood education in or outside of Hong Kong, leading to a reflection on the existing practice in early childhood settings by making connections between research and practice. During the tour, participants will visit local or overseas institutions specializing in early childhood education, nurseries, kindergartens, and exchange on children development and curriculum implementation, as well as collect relevant data on early childhood education setting. Students are required to submit a study report after the visits.
outcome: At the end of this study tour, students are expected to:  1. Through the observation of classes and children’s daily activities to critically examine factors employed by the visiting schools in facilitating children’s physical, cognitive and social-emotional development. The factors may include visiting schools’ design of curriculum, arrangements of environment and resources, roles of teachers, etc. 2. Critique the educational leadership and management of the visiting schools. 3. From relevant theoretical and comparative perspectives to reflect on the contemporary local and overseas early childhood education practices, and to propose ways for improvement. 4. Through class observation, data collection, participation of seminar and submission of study report, etc., to enrich practical knowledge of early childhood education and enhance professional capacity for putting theories into practice.  (Individual course teachers may update the learning outcome as and whenever necessary.)
